prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral and Correlator Configurations: For all sources we have configured a single baseband at higher resolution (FDM), in which our target CO line is centered. In all cases we have included spectral averaging to just less than 10km/s, as our lens modeling will use the full spectral information until reaching the practical limit imposed by the velocity widths of individual structures in the galaxy. In the case of a single source (2134-50) we shift the CO line slightly to include both CO 7-6 and CI in the baseband. The remaining basebands are configured for TDM mode for continuum sensitivity.
Imaging Requirements: We request spatial resolution of 0.3" in all sources except 2134-50 (0.2"). This is approximately the highest achievable resolution for each of our chosen lines. Higher spatial resolution improves the lensing sensitivity, but there is a significant increase in uncertainty in the CO line fluxes at higher transitions (and thus higher resolution), and the line fluxes can be expected to decrease beyond the transitions (6-5 to 8-7, depending on availability) chosen here. Our sensitivity simulations were performed using the line fluxes and resolution selected here, and the resulting expectation of 10 subhalo detections matches our goal for the project.
Sensitivity Requirements: Our simulations were conducted assuming 10 km/s channelization of the spectra, so we use this as our reference bandwidth for all calculations. Our noise target of 0.7mJy per 10km/s was determined from our simulations as providing our 10 subhalo goal for these objects.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe five strongly lensed, dusty, star forming galaxies for ∼ 40 minutes per source in CO emission lines in bands 4 and 6 to detect dark matter subhalos in the lens galaxies using gravitationally-induced perturbations they cause on the images of background sources. With detailed simulations, we have shown that ALMA is capable of efficiently detecting subhalos in these systems, if the abundance of subhalos is in agreement with ΛCDM predictions. We have built and tested a complete pipeline to search for and detect subhalos using ALMA data. This proposal is a pilot study for the analysis of the large population of bright lensed dusty galaxies discovered in submm bands to detect dark matter subhalos, allowing us to measure their mass function with unprecedented accuracy and thereby resolve one of the most important puzzles in modern cosmology.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology, Stanford University
